conclusion: Analyze the motion of the slider and the ball through the different sections of the track, considering energy conservation, friction, and collision dynamics.
Slider starts from rest at height h above the platform and slides down inclined track AB with angle θ = 37°.
The frictional force on the slider is f = μmg cos θ.
The work done by friction as the slider moves from P to B is W_f = μmg cos θ · s, where s is the distance traveled along the incline.
Using energy conservation, the potential energy at P is converted into kinetic energy at B minus the work done by friction: mgh = 1/2mv^2 + μmg cos θ · s.
Solving for v gives the velocity of the slider at B.
Slider collides elastically with a ball of equal mass at rest.
In an elastic collision between two equal masses, the slider comes to rest, and the ball takes on the velocity of the slider.
Ball's velocity after the collision is v.
Ball moves through smooth quarter-circular pipe CD and semi-circular track DEF.
Ball must have enough kinetic energy to reach the highest point E on the track DEF.
At point E, ball's potential energy is mg(2R) (since E is at height 2R above O2).
Using energy conservation from B to E: 1/2mv^2 = mg(2R).
Solving for v gives the minimum velocity required for the ball to reach point E.
After passing point F, ball moves vertically downwards and collides with triangular prism G.
Collision changes direction of ball's velocity to horizontal, but magnitude remains the same.
Horizontal velocity of the ball is v.
Ball falls from height H + 2R to the ground.
Using projectile motion, time t to fall is determined by: H + 2R = 1/2gt^2 implies t = sqrt(2(H + 2R)/g).
Horizontal distance x traveled by the ball is: x = vt.
Calculate maximum horizontal distance x_max.
